text: I suppose that this is where the drone boys or tracksiders get their money? GPS can't tell you that a runner "looks" like its got plenty in hand. No way to tell if a horse is just running badly or being intentionally held until the last minute - but if market sentiment suggests its got plenty left you could infer it that way. Not speaking for the others here who may well have found ways to spot this kind is situation using the raw GPS but I would not know where to start without also utilising market sentiment.

text: When you talk about getting "fooled" I think that the general GPS data inaccuracies that we all have to deal with are the biggest factor to consider. Sometimes the data is poor and we just have to factor that in. Horses, jockeys (and sometimes GPS data) are unreliable beasts and we just have to live with it. Even an animal with the potential to win at a given stage of the race may not actually produce - for a variety of reasons.

elements.text: When you talk about getting "fooled" I think that the general GPS data inaccuracies that we all have to deal with are the biggest factor to consider. text: Haha, no I agree. You're really planning for the general case rather than the exceptions so you're apt to get caught out by something like this (although it doesn't look like I was in this case). For my part I incorporate a lot of market signals in my GPS operation so I expect that mitigates things to an extent.

elements.text: Haha, no I agree.
